Award.AwardTitle: International Summer School on Data Science for Scattering Reactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide partial support for a summer school focused on the theory and phenomenology of relativistic scattering and its practical implementations in data analysis of modern experiments in hadron physics. The organizers propose to bring together experts in hadrons spectroscopy and interested students, post-docs, staff and faculty for a series of lectures and laboratory sessions. The lectures given at the school will be recorded and used to develop online resources that can be used for future training purposes.

This Summer School is intended to address a critical need in the community with respect to the training of a new generation of physicists in advanced scattering theory in response to the specific needs of data analysis at experimental programs at facilities such as the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider at Brookhaven and the Jefferson National Laboratory. The data sets generated of these facilities are of unprecedented quality and will demand a qualitatively new level of sophistication in analysis never before achieved. As such, the summer school will provide an unique opportunity for scientists in the field of hadronic physics to enhance their training by interacting with recognized experts in this field.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This proposal gave partial support to a two week Graduate Summer School dedicated to theory and data science for the analysis of modern experiments involving strong interactions physics. This is the physics studying the interactions of protons, neutrons, mesons such as pions and Kaons and photons. The School took place at the campus of Indiana University in Bloomington, IN, June 7-21, 2015 and was a collaboration between NSF, Indiana University and the Thomas Jefferson National Accelerator Facility. This event was preceded by substantial planning activities and followed by a survey and the organization of material on the web site to form a permanent knowledge repository at the project website http://www.indiana.edu/~ssrt/. The event brought  together experts in the field and interested students, post-docs, staff and faculty for a series of lectures and laboratory sessions around this data analysis challenge. It covered a broad range of expert lectures and a set of tutorials on the AmpTools software designed to analyze strong interaction physics data. The material presented spanned ideas such as “Regge” and “S-Matrix” Theory that were developed some time ago (1970-1980) and are not well known to current practitioners, as well as new ideas such as QCD simulations and the quark model that are actively researched today.

 

The demographics of this training and professional development event were 19 Total Speakers for 34 Registered participants, which included 23 graduate students and 7 postdocs. There were 20 domestic, and 14 foreign participants where latter came from Canada, Germany, Spain, Italy, Belgium, France, Sweden, Egypt, Greece, Kenya, China, Russia, and the U.K. Among participants, there were 3 women, 1 African-American, 1  Hispanic/Latino, and 1  Hispanic/White.
